{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=March 2009}}
A '''third place playoff''', '''match/game for third place''', '''bronze medal game''' or '''consolation game''' is a single match that is included in many [[sport]]ing [[knockout tournament]]s to decide which competitor or team will be credited with finishing third and fourth. The teams that compete in the third place playoff game are usually the two losing [[semi-final]]ists in a particular knockout tournament.
Many tournaments use the third place playoff to determine who wins the [[bronze medal]]. In some tournaments, a third place playoff is necessary for seeding purposes if three or all four semi-finalists advance to another tournament.
In tournaments that do not award medals or have the third place finisher advance to something else, a third place playoff is a [[classification match]] that serves little more than as a consolation to the losing semi-finalists. A consolation game also allows teams to play more than one game after having invested time, effort and money in the quest for a championship. Third place playoffs held as such consolation games are subject to debate. Many sports tournaments do not have a third place playoff due to a lack of interest. It has been criticised by some who feel that the match serves little purpose, but others see this game as an occasion for the losing semi-finalists to salvage some pride. How seriously the competitors or teams take a third place playoff, may also be mixed: a heavily favoured team that lost in an upset in the semi-final round may not have as much incentive to win as would a [[Cinderella (sports)|"Cinderella" team]] who was not expected to advance that far.
==Olympics== Most sports using a knockout format in the [[Olympic Games]] have a third place game to determine who wins the [[bronze medal]], with the exception being [[Boxing at the Summer Olympics|boxing]] which awards two bronze medals ([[Judo at the Summer Olympics|judo]], [[Taekwondo at the Summer Olympics|taekwondo]], and [[Wrestling at the Summer Olympics|wrestling]], which also award two bronze medals, both feature two bronze medal matches, between the losing semi-finalists and the winners of the [[repechage]]). As the difference between a bronze medal and no medal is quite significant, competitors still take this game seriously.
==IRB Rugby World Cup== The [[Rugby World Cup]] used to give automatic qualification to all teams in the top three of the ongoing tournament to the one that would follow it four years later thus making the third place playoff game important, but this was later scrapped after the 1999 edition of the tournament allowing teams outside the top three to automatically qualify depending on their IRB co-efficient in the rankings.
==FIFA World Cup and other association football tournaments== The [[UEFA Euro 1980|1980 edition]] was the last [[UEFA European Football Championship]] to have a third place match. That was one of the few third place football matches ever to be decided by a penalty shootout, where [[Czechoslovakia national football team|Czechoslovakia]] defeated hosts [[Italy national football team|Italy]] 9-8.
The [[FIFA World Cup]] features a third place playoff, usually on the day before the final. It is often there to provide a spectacle as there is often a gap of a few days between the semi-finals and the final. The third place playoff is considered a lower-priority match to organizers, as it is frequently scheduled in one of the smaller stadia; the largest stadium (usually located in the host nation's capital city) is reserved for the final, while the semi-finals occupy the second and third-largest stadia. However, the [[1994 FIFA World Cup#Third-place match|third place match]] in the 1994 World Cup did use the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]] stadium, the same venue that would later host the tournament final, setting a record attendance of 91,500 for a third place playoff in FIFA World Cup history.
The [[UEFA Nations League]] will also have a third place playoff, this game will be played on the same day as the final.
The third-place match in the [[FIFA Women's World Cup]] has been somewhat more important to the organizers—the [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup#Match for third place|1999]], [[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup#Third Place|2003]], and [[2007 FIFA Women's World Cup#Third place playoff|2007]] matches were all held in the same stadium as the final. In fact, the 1999 and 2007 third-place matches were both held as the first half of a doubleheader that culminated in the final. The [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup#Third place play-off|2011]] third-place match returned to the more traditional scheduling of the day before the final in a different stadium. Notably, the 1999 third-place match was the curtain-raiser to the most-attended women's sporting event in history, the [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup Final|1999 final]] also held in the Rose Bowl.
The third place match is generally a high-scoring affair, as no men's match has seen fewer than two goals scored since Poland's 1-0 win over Brazil in 1974, while all bronze-medal games since 1994 (except for 1998, 2014 and 2018) have seen four goals or more. For tournament top scorers, the third place match's tendency of attacking football is a great opportunity to win the Golden Shoe, with players such as [[Salvatore Schillaci]] (1990), [[Davor Šuker]] (1998), and [[Thomas Müller]] (2010) getting the goal they needed to take sole possession of the lead.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/418354-3rd4th-play-off-preview|title=2010 FIFA World Cup: Third Place Play-Off Preview Germany vs. Uruguay|first=Eugene|last=Fogarty|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> The [[FIFA Women's World Cup]] has had only seven editions to date, therefore creating less opportunity for a pattern to form. However, two of the third-place games in that competition have seen fewer than three goals. In 1995, the [[United States women's national soccer team|USA]] defeated [[China women's national football team|China]] 2–0. In 1999, the third-place match between [[Brazil women's national football team|Brazil]] and [[Norway women's national football team|Norway]] ended in a scoreless draw and penalty shootout (won by Brazil), as did the final between the USA and China (won by the USA). In 2015, the third place match between [[Germany women's national football team|Germany]] and [[England women's national football team|England]] was the first to go to extra time, and in the second period of extra time, England scored a single penalty kick goal and held on to the lead to upset Germany.
How seriously the competing teams take this match is subject to debate. Certain teams, especially ones which had been expected to reach the final, will rest some of their starters to allow some of their reserve team players to participate in a World Cup game. For instance French team captain [[Michel Platini]] did not play in either the 1982 or 1986 third place matches, while German goalkeeper [[Hans-Jörg Butt]] received his only competitive international appearance in a third place playoff<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/sport/worldcup2010/2010/07/2010710194753550606.html|title=Germany beat Uruguay to bronze|website=www.aljazeera.com|accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4991644.stm|title=Germany 3-1 Portugal|date=8 July 2006|publisher=BBC|accessdate=10 July 2018}}</ref>, and [[Michel Vorm]] came on during injury time of the 3–0 third place play-off win against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in [[Brasília]] thus ensuring that all 23 Dutch squad members played at the tournament.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28173517|title=Brazil 0–3 Netherlands|date=12 July 2014|accessdate=13 July 2014|publisher=BBC}}</ref> By contrast, [[Cinderella (sports)|teams that are not expected to get this far]] usually take this match seriously, as third place can be a historical achievement. In the 1994 World Cup, the Sweden national team branded the game as "the bronze match" and after victory they landed at Arlanda with a fighter escort and were then paraded through the streets of Stockholm to millions live on national TV. Another example of a high-profile third place match was in [[1998 FIFA World Cup|1998]], when the recently established [[Croatian national football team|Croatian football team]] upset the Netherlands.
If the host nation is involved in the third place match, the team generally uses the match to thank the support of their fans (such as the [[South Korea national football team|South Korean football team]] in [[2002 FIFA World Cup|2002]], and the [[Germany national football team|German football team]] in [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006]]).<ref name="auto"/> German [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] [[Oliver Kahn]], who had been a reserve to [[Jens Lehmann]] during the 2006 tournament, was allowed to retire in the third place playoff by then manager [[Jürgen Klinsmann]]. Germany and Portugal fielded strong lineups in that match, after both were narrowly eliminated in their respective semi-finals (Germany and Italy nearly went to a penalty shootout,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4991640.stm|title=Last-gasp Italy knock Germany out|date=4 July 2006|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2018|via=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> while Portugal was defeated by the lower-ranked France<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4991632.stm|title=Portugal 0-1 France|date=5 July 2006|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2018|via=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>). For [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], the dismal 3–0 loss to the Netherlands in the 2014 third place match, along with the [[Brazil v Germany (2014 FIFA World Cup)|7-1 semi-final defeat to Germany]], led to coach [[Luiz Felipe Scolari]] being dismissed.<ref>https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28173517]</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/world-cup-disaster-leaves-scolari-reputation-tainted-025054984--sow.html | title=World Cup disaster leaves Scolari reputation tainted | date=13 July 2014 | publisher=AFP | via=Yahoo | first=Andy | last=Scott | accessdate=10 July 2018 }}</ref> For the Dutch, this was their first bronze medal in the FIFA World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/dcunited/netherlands-leads-host-brazil-2-0-at-halftime/2014/07/12/4dbde078-0a06-11e4-85e4-3143dddacfe9_story.html|title=- The Washington Post|website=Washington Post|accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref>
Germany currently holds the most third-place finishes in the (men's) World Cup, with four, their most recent in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/soccer/third-place-magic-for-germany/article1635808/|title=Third-place magic for Germany|date=10 July 2010|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2018|via=The Globe and Mail}}</ref> The U.S. has the most third-place finishes in the Women's World Cup, with three; they have never finished outside the top three.
==Little League World Series== For most of its history, the [[Little League World Series]] has featured either a consolation bracket, or consolation games. Currently, the tournament features a single consolation game between the United States runner-up and the International runner-up. Like the championship, the game allows an American team to compete against an International team. All other games are played within their respective American or International pool of eight teams each, except two exhibition games which match the United States teams and International teams which went 0-2 in their respective brackets.
==Early season College Basketball Tournaments== Third place games (and consolation games for lower placings) are common in early season college basketball tournaments, as it gives each team an opportunity to play more games before the conference games start in earnest. It also provides the tournament venue with additional games.
==Defunct third place playoff games== Many sports tournaments do not have a third place playoff, mostly due to a lack of interest from the competitors and also from the fans. Two of the most celebrated knockout tournaments — the [[FA Cup Third-fourth place matches]] (1970–1974) and the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship]] (1946–1981) — did feature the third place game for a period of time, but later abandoned it. For most of its years, the NCAA consolation game held interest because it usually featured two nationally ranked teams in which only a few teams qualified for the tournament. However, as the field expanded beyond 32 teams, the game lost significance.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} In addition, eliminating the game allowed the losing teams to return home rather than remaining in the Final Four city for an additional two days to play a game many{{who|date=April 2017}} believed was irrelevant. Relevancy aside, others{{who|date=April 2017}} supported the game for competitive reasons because it typically featured a match between two of the best college teams in the nation; and, it allowed each of those teams to be honored as a Final Four team for the entire weekend.
The [[National Football League]] had a consolation game, the [[Playoff Bowl]], from {{nfly|1960}} to {{nfly|1969}}, which pitted the second-place team in each of the two conferences (based on regular season record from 1960 to {{nfly|1966}}) against each other in [[Miami Orange Bowl|Miami]], [[Florida]]. Through the 1966 season, the only scheduled NFL playoff game was the [[History of the National Football League championship|Championship Game]] (with unscheduled conference tie-breaker games as necessary; only in [[1965 NFL playoffs|1965]] during the 1960s). In {{nfly|1967}}, the [[1967 NFL playoffs|NFL playoff field]] expanded to four (division champions), and its first round losers went to the Playoff Bowl, increasingly unpopular with the participating players. With interest declining for a third-place game and an [[1970–71 NFL playoffs|eight-team playoff field]] arriving with the [[AFL–NFL merger]] in {{nfly|1970}}, the Playoff Bowl was abandoned with little objection.
Third place playoffs are especially controversial when they are used in tournaments that use a [[Page playoff system]] since there is only one "semi-final" game in this format. Critics argue that in such a formula, the loser of the semi-final should simply be awarded third place. Proponents of the third place game argue that without it, the importance of the [[medal round]] is cheapened since the top two teams heading into the Page playoff would otherwise be "guaranteed" a medal - this argument carries less weight in tournaments where medals are not awarded or where they are considered of relatively minor importance in comparison to winning the tournament.

'''[[Tobacco]]''' usage in '''[[sport]]''' is a well documented and publicised occurrence. [[Tobacco advertising]] has connected itself to sports both for the connotations of health that sports provide, as well as the marketing potential of famous athletes. Additionally, tobacco has played a role in the sport of [[baseball]] specifically and has affected both the rules affecting players and fan alike. Agencies such as the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] have used sports as platforms for tobacco prevention programs, specifically targeted at younger people.
==Advertising== [[File:White Borders baseball card reverse.JPG|thumb|Back of an old baseball card]] For many years, [[Tobacco industry|tobacco companies]] have played a monumental role in advertising within the sports industry. Major tobacco companies have employed the strategies of athletic endorsements, sponsorships of major athletic events, and creating powerful associations of tobacco and active lifestyles in order to advertise their products. The connection between sports and tobacco can be traced back to the origins of professional sports.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.faverodental.com/2015/02/smokeless-tobacco-and-baseball/|title=Favero Family Dental {{!}} Smokeless Tobacco and Baseball|website=www.faverodental.com|access-date=2016-05-15}}</ref> Shortly after the [[National League|National Baseball League]]'s inception in 1876, [[Baseball card|trading cards]] with player's images emerged within cigarette packages.<ref name="autogenerated1">[http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/14/1/1.full#xref-ref-2-1 Tobacco in sport: an endless addiction?] Tob Control 2005;14:1-2</ref> One of the oldest brands of [[chewing tobacco]], [[W. T. Blackwell and Company Tobacco Factory|Bull Durham]], advertised on outfield fences in [[baseball park]]s in the United States South.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Despite this long-standing history, there have been many recent developments and changes in tobacco's relation to athletics. Currently, trends have shifted as athletes today are more likely to endorse tobacco prevention efforts as opposed to tobacco products.
===Endorsements=== From the 1920s to 1940s baseball furthered its relation with tobacco. Every major league team had a cigarette sponsor and baseball's greatest athletes such as [[Babe Ruth]], [[Joe DiMaggio]], and [[Ted Williams]], all appeared in cigarette advertisements.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[Lou Gehrig]] endorsed [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company|R. J. Reynolds]]’ [[Camel (cigarette)|Camels]], saying he could smoke as many as he pleased and creating the slogan that Camels “don’t get your wind.”<ref>{{Cite book |last= Brandt |first= Allan |title= The Cigarette Century |publisher=[[Basic Books]] |date=2007 |isbn=0-465-07047-7}}</ref>
As tensions mounted in the 1950s, with smoking's correlation to [[lung cancer]], the [[Commissioner of Baseball (MLB)|Commissioner of Baseball]] prohibited players from wearing their uniforms in cigarette advertisements. While baseball cracked down on endorsements, the [[National Football League]] not only permitted players to appear in tobacco advertisements but also signed [[Altria Group|Philip Morris]]’ [[Marlboro (cigarette)|Marlboro]] as its major television sponsor.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Of these players, one of the most prominent was [[Frank Gifford]]. Gifford played for the [[New York Giants]] in the 1950s and 1960s and later became a famous sportscaster. In his prime, Gifford endorsed a wide range of products, including The [[American Tobacco Company]]'s [[Lucky Strike]] cigarettes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pophistorydig.com/?tag=tobacco-advertising-1960s |title=tobacco advertising 1960s |publisher=The Pop History Dig |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref>
In 1964, the tobacco industry began to anticipate increased federal regulation and voluntarily adopted the Cigarette Advertising Code, stating it would not “depict as a smoker any person well known as being, or having been, an athlete…[or] any person participating in, or obviously having just participated in, physical activity requiring stamina or athletic conditioning beyond that of normal recreation”. Under this code, athletes and celebrities were no longer allowed to give testimonials, but nonetheless the industry blatantly disregarded its own guidelines.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
In October 2009, Baisha, [[China]]’s largest cigarette company, signed [[Liu Xiang (hurdler)|Liu Xiang]], an Olympic gold medalist hurdler, to endorse its cigarettes in both print advertisements and televised commercials.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
===Sponsorships=== Traditionally, cigarette companies have had a strong relationship with [[Tobacco advertising#NASCAR auto racing|NASCAR events]]. After tobacco companies were forced to pull out of advertising in [[NASCAR]], [[Nicorette]] has entered the NASCAR arena and signed a three-year contract as part of an extension by GlaxoSmithKline, then the owner of Goody's Headache Powders, a long-time NASCAR sponsor.<ref name="usatoday2005">{{cite web|last=Horovitz |first=Bruce |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/advertising/2005-01-26-nascar-usat_x.htm |title=Nicorette, NASCAR sign sponsorship deal |publisher=Usatoday.Com |date=2005-01-27 |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref> NASCAR's deal with Nicorette was only for one year. Winston stepped down after 33 years as title sponsor of NASCAR's championship series and was replaced by Nextel.<ref name="usatoday2005"/> Nicorette sees a great market as NASCAR fans are 28% more likely to smoke than other adults. The firm also reported that they smoke 18% more cigarettes than other adults.<ref name="usatoday2005"/> Since Nicorette has signed on as a sponsor, there has been a substantial decrease in the amount of NASCAR employees who smoke. Nicorette began its quit smoking program in 2004, providing NASCAR members with training sessions and one-on-one counseling. Additionally, Nicorette has counseled about 250,000 race fans on how to quit smoking since 2005.<ref>[http://www.nascar.com/2008/news/features/10/31 ]{{Dead link|date=July 2010}}</ref>
Cigarette companies have explored the sponsorship of rodeo since the early 1970s. From 1986 to 2009 the [[Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association]] was sponsored by the [[U.S. Smokeless Tobacco Company]] as well as the [[National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association]] (NIRA) since 1974.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ling|first=Pamela M.|last2=Haber|first2=Lawrence A.|last3=Wedl|first3=Stefani|title=Branding the Rodeo: A Case Study of Tobacco Sports Sponsorship|url=http://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/abs/10.2105/AJPH.2008.144097|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=100|issue=1|pages=32–41|doi=10.2105/ajph.2008.144097|pmid=19910357|pmc=2791245}}</ref> The association severed its ties with the tobacco industry in 2009, allowing [[rodeo]] culture to return to its status before tobacco's involvement in 1986. “Cowboy Ted” Hallisey, a prominent print and broadcast journalist for rodeo events stated “Without [[big tobacco]], rodeos will move into mainstream sports because they will be more comfortable for children and families to attend”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tobacco-facts.net/2009/12/professional-rodeo-cowboys-association-ends-tobacco-sponsorship |title=Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association Ends Tobacco Sponsorship | Tobacco Facts |publisher=Tobacco Facts. |date=2009-12-02 |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref>
===Advertising strategies=== In the early 1900s the tobacco industry sought to pair smoking with active and healthy lifestyles. Through its advertisements, the tobacco industry created associations between smoking and recreational and athletic activities like tennis, golf, swimming, football, track and field, skiing, and ice skating. These activities were often depicted in cigarette advertising as activities demanding a cigarette for enhanced performance and even good health. American Tobacco's Lucky Strikes ran a successful advertising campaign that urged men and women “To keep a slender figure, reach for a Lucky instead of a sweet.” {{Cite book |last= Brandt |first= Allan |title= The Cigarette Century |publisher=[[Basic Books]] |date=2007 |page=78 |isbn=0-465-07047-7}} Smokeless tobacco in baseball urged adolescents to buy their product by using slogans such as "May cause the urge to act like a man."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tobaccofreebaseball.org/content/|title=Knock Tobacco Out of the Park|website=tobaccofreebaseball.org|access-date=2016-05-13}}</ref>
=== Advertising and Sponsorship in Australia === One of the first countries to ever legislate the end of tobacco advertising and sponsorship at sporting events was Australia.<ref name=":0" />
Quit Victoria in Australia, stated that the three major sponsors for sport in 1980 were the largest tobacco companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tobaccoinaustralia.org.au/fandi/fandi/c15s5.htm|title=15.5 Sponsorship|website=www.tobaccoinaustralia.org.au|access-date=2016-05-12}}</ref> In 1989, the tobacco industry put a whopping 34 million dollars into [[cricket]] and [[rugby league]]. Although advertisement of tobacco products on television had been banned in 1976, on ground advertising and naming rights to oppositions and events was tactically used by tobacco companies; for example, the [[Benson & Hedges|Benson and Hedges]] logo would appear for approximately 90 minutes in a day’s play of [[test cricket]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.clearinghouseforsport.gov.au/knowledge_base/organised_sport/sport_integrity/tobacco_sponsorship_and_advertising_in_sport|title=Clearinghouse for Sport|last=|first=|date=|website=Tobacco Sponsorship and Advertising in Sport|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> The tobacco advertising [[Prohibition Act|prohibition act]] 1992, prohibited nearly all of tobaccos advertising and sponsorships in sporting events. However, under section 18 of the Act, there was power to allow an exception to the general ban on tobacco advertising in Australia for sporting events of international significance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2016C00440|title=Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992|last=Health|website=www.legislation.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2016-05-12}}</ref> In 2000, there was an amendment to remove this act and Australian sport became totally tobacco sponsorship and advertisement free in October 2006.<ref name=":0" />
== Smokeless tobacco == [[Smokeless tobacco]]: [[chewing tobacco]], [[Dipping tobacco|spit tobacco]], [[Snuff (tobacco)|dry snuff]], [[snus]], or ‘tabac à chiquer’ in France, is very common in some sports.<ref name=":1" /> There is little data on the number of athletes that use smokeless tobacco, but a study showed that approximately 45 percent of major league baseball players have been reported to use smokeless tobacco.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chiamulera|first=Cristiano|last2=Leone|first2=Roberto|last3=Fumagalli|first3=Guido|date=2007-12-01|title=Smokeless tobacco use in sports: ‘legal doping’?|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1360-0443.2007.01993.x/abstract|journal=Addiction|language=en|volume=102|issue=12|pages=1847–1848|doi=10.1111/j.1360-0443.2007.01993.x|issn=1360-0443}}</ref> Athletes apparently used smokeless tobacco to enhance their performance because nicotine improved certain aspects of physiology.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Chagué|first=Frédéric|last2=Guenancia|first2=Charles|last3=Gudjoncik|first3=Aurélie|last4=Moreau|first4=Daniel|last5=Cottin|first5=Yves|last6=Zeller|first6=Marianne|title=Smokeless tobacco, sport and the heart|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1875213614002678|journal=Archives of Cardiovascular Diseases|volume=108|issue=1|pages=75–83|doi=10.1016/j.acvd.2014.10.003}}</ref> However, it has been found that smokeless tobacco can cause many harmful health effects such as [[cancer]], mouth and tooth problems, [[Cardiovascular disease|heart disease]] and [[Hypertension|high blood pressure]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cancer.org/cancer/cancercauses/tobaccocancer/smokeless-tobacco|title=Health Risks of Smokeless Tobacco|website=www.cancer.org|access-date=2016-05-13}}</ref> [[File:Tuggtobak.jpg|thumb|Chewing Tobacco]]
==Baseball and tobacco== Between 1920 until 1940, when baseball was Americas most popular sport, every team had a tobacco sponsor.<ref name="autogenerated1" /> It is common perception that many baseball players use tobacco. According to the [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] however this practice is changing and declining.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|author=Mychael Urban / MLB.com |url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20080630&content_id=3037249&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb |title=Tobacco use in baseball on the decline | MLB.com: News |publisher=Mlb.mlb.com |date=2008-06-30 |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref> One source states that a reason chewing tobacco usage increased among baseball players was the misconception that it improved concentration, overall performance and was less harmful than smoking a cigarette. Contrary to this, chewing tobacco does not have an established connection to the performance of baseball players.<ref name="publichealthgreybruce1">{{cite web|url=http://www.publichealthgreybruce.on.ca/Tobacco/Chewing/Sports.htm |title=Chewing Tobacco - Sports |publisher=Publichealthgreybruce.on.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref> As more information about [[Health effects of tobacco#Particular forms of tobacco use|the dangers of chewing tobacco]] has come to light it has become stigmatized within baseball itself with players, staff and managers often having to "sneak" off to partake. These individuals understand that children will easily copy their actions and try to hide them now, as they are negative role models for youth. Most players have made attempts to quit, but the majority struggle in breaking their addiction.<ref name="costkids1">{{cite web |url=http://www.costkids.org/tobacco/smokelesstobacco/smokelesstobacco.htm |title=Smokeless Tobacco |publisher=Costkids.org |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628060817/http://www.costkids.org/tobacco/smokelesstobacco/smokelesstobacco.htm |archivedate=2010-06-28 |df= }}</ref> [[Lenny Dykstra]], the former [[Philadelphia Phillies]] center-fielder, started [[Dipping tobacco|dipping]] at a young age, unaware of how difficult quitting would be. He tells young children, "They call me "Nails" because they say I'm as tough as nails. But I'm not tough enough to beat the spit-tobacco habit. Copy my hustle, copy my determination. But don't copy my spit-tobacco habit."<ref name="costkids1"/> In addition Major League Baseball has taken actions to lower tobacco usage amongst its players. This includes a complete ban on tobacco with fines for players and their managers if it is discovered. In the major leagues tobacco companies are no longer allowed to leave free products in stadium clubhouses for the players, with a ban effective December 5, 2016, in the new Collective Bargaining Agreement that prohibits players entering MLB for the first time from using tobacco. (Players who had experience in MLB prior to the day are grandfathered.) <ref name="autogenerated2"/> Baseball stadiums have stricter tobacco policies for patrons as well though the level of strictness varies per stadium.<ref name="no-smoke1">[http://www.no-smoke.org/pdf/majorleaguebaseballstadiumpoliices.pdf Smoking Policies at Major League Baseball Stadiums], May 24, 2010</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+A breakdown of [[Major League Baseball]] teams by stadium smoking policies.<ref name="no-smoke1"/> |- ! Team ! No smoking allowed (no re-entry) ! Re-entry allowed for Smoking ! Designated smoking inside ! Designated smoking within grounds |- | [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[Atlanta Braves]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Baltimore Orioles]] | | | | style="text-align:center;"| X |- | [[Boston Red Sox]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Chicago Cubs]] | |style="text-align:center;"| x | | |- | [[Chicago White Sox]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Cincinnati Reds]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Cleveland Indians]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Colorado Rockies]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Detroit Tigers]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Houston Astros]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Kansas City Royals]] | | | | style="text-align:center;"| X |- | [[Los Angeles Angels]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[Miami Marlins]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Milwaukee Brewers]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Minnesota Twins]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[New York Mets]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[New York Yankees]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Oakland Athletics]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Philadelphia Phillies]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[St. Louis Cardinals]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[San Diego Padres]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[San Francisco Giants]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Seattle Mariners]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[Tampa Bay Rays]] | | | | style="text-align:center;"| X |- | [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Toronto Blue Jays]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Washington Nationals]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |}
==Tobacco prevention and sports== The majority of tobacco smokers start smoking before they graduate high school. The CDC has identified youth sports as an area where tobacco education and prevention will help limit the number of first time smokers and has begun a Tobacco Free Sports Movement to encourage non smoking practices in athletics.<ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/youth/sports/index.htm |title=Smoking and Tobacco Use :: Youth Tobacco Prevention :: Tobacco-Free Sports Initiatives :: Office on Smoking and Health (OSH) :: CDC |publisher=Cdc.gov |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref> The CDC has paired with many large organizations to achieve this goal. These include public health agencies such as the [[National Cancer Institute]], and sport regulatory bodies such as [[FIFA]] and the [[International Olympic Committee]] to further the efforts of tobacco elimination in sports.<ref name="autogenerated3"/> The [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Beijing Olympics]] banned not only tobacco usage, but advertising, sponsorship, promotion and sale of tobacco products in Olympic venues.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wpro.who.int/china/sites/tfi/tfo.htm |title=WHO China-Tobacco-free Olympics |publisher=Wpro.who.int |date=2010-05-27 |accessdate=2010-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713060044/http://www.wpro.who.int/china/sites/tfi/tfo.htm |archivedate=2010-07-13 |df= }}</ref> The last Olympics with a tobacco company as a sponsor were in 1984, and control has gotten stricter since then (as can be seen from the Beijing regulations).<ref name="autogenerated4">[http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/14/1/1.full Tobacco in sport: an endless addiction?] Tob Control 2005;14:1-2</ref> On a smaller scale there are regional efforts to create tobacco free sports initiatives such as the Tobacco-Free Athletes of Maine. This organization seeks to have coaches educate their young athletes about the effects of tobacco.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tobaccofreemaine.org/channels/educators/tobacco_free_athletes.php |title=Tobacco-Free Athletes - Tobacco Prevention for Youth in Sports & Community Programs - Partnership For A Tobacco-Free Maine |publisher=Tobaccofreemaine.org |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref>
Many athletes have become spokespersons for [[Tobacco control movement|anti-tobacco]] and tobacco prevention efforts. Early in the 20th century Hall of Fame baseball player [[Honus Wagner]] would not allow a cigarette company to use his picture on a tobacco trading card.<ref name="autogenerated4"/> Since then famous athletes like skateboarder [[Tony Hawk]]<ref name="autogenerated3"/> and baseball player [[Sammy Sosa]] have supported tobacco prevention.<ref name="publichealthgreybruce1"/> Events such as the [[American Cancer Society]]'s [[Great American Smokeout]] also make use of athletes to support their anti-tobacco efforts. In 2000, the American Cancer Society had [[Alonzo Mourning]] of the [[Miami Heat]] (with other athletes) speak to children about the dangers of smoking.<ref name="cancer1">[http://www.cancer.org/docroot/NWS/content/NWS_1_1x_Athletes_Pitch_in_to_Send_Quit_Smoking_Message_during_Great_American_Smokeout.asp ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025103726/http://www.cancer.org/docroot/NWS/content/NWS_1_1x_Athletes_Pitch_in_to_Send_Quit_Smoking_Message_during_Great_American_Smokeout.asp |date=October 25, 2008 }}</ref>
Recently in the [[2010 Winter Olympics]], the [[Canada women's national ice hockey team]] celebrated their gold medal victory on the ice with both cigars and tobacco. As the Vancouver Olympics were a tobacco free event, the International Olympic Committee decided to look into the celebration since it was a breach of anti-tobacco rules.<ref>{{cite web|author=CBSSports.com wire reports |url=http://www.cbssports.com/olympics/story/12978672/ioc-to-look-into-drinking-celebrations-on-ice-by-women-hockey-team |title=IOC to look into drinking celebrations on ice by women's hockey team - Olympics |publisher=CBSSports.com |date=2010-02-26 |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref>
===List of athletes who have supported tobacco prevention in sport=== * [[Tony Hawk]]<ref name="autogenerated3"/> * [[Honus Wagner]]<ref name="autogenerated4"/> * [[Alonzo Mourning]]<ref name="cancer1"/> * [[Jerome Bettis]]<ref name="cancer1"/> * [[Cris Carter]]<ref name="cancer1"/> * [[Ben Grieve]]<ref name="cancer1"/>
==See also== *[[Smokeless tobacco]] *[[Tobacco advertising]] *[[Chewing tobacco]] *[[Smoking]]
{{Portal|Sports}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.tobaccofreesports.ca/ Tobacco Free Sports], Canada

revision.text:
{{for|the previous protests|U.S. national anthem protests}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox civil conflict | latitude = | longitude = | image = [[File:Colin Kaepernick in 2013.jpg|200px]] | caption = [[Colin Kaepernick]] with the [[San Francisco 49ers]] (2013) | date = August 14, 2016–ongoing ({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|year1=2016|month1=8|day1=14}}) | place = [[List of current National Football League stadiums|National Football League stadiums]] | coordinates = | goals = Protest [[Police brutality in the United States|police brutality]] and [[Racial inequality in the United States|racial inequality]] in the United States<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/04/sports/nike-protests-kaepernick-nfl-.html|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=September 4, 2018|title=Nike’s Deal With Kaepernick Draws Cheers and Pictures of Burning Shoes|date=September 4, 2018|first1= Jacey|last1=Fortin|first2=Matthew|last2=Haag}}</ref> | methods = [[Peaceful protest]] | status = | result = | concessions = | side1 = | side2 = | leadfigures1 = | leadfigures2 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties_label = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = }}
Since August 2016, some U.S. athletes have silently protested against systematic oppression,<ref name="Sporting News">{{cite web|title=NFL players protest during anthem; Colin Kaepernick, President Trump respond'|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/us/nfl/news/nfl-players-protest-during-national-anthem-colin-kaepernick-tweets-support/o3v0jxys8jbc1cr2gkzxpcb9n/|publisher=''[[Sporting News]]''|accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref> equality and social injustice,<ref name="USAToday">{{cite web|title=Aaron Rodgers sticks up for player protests during national anthem'|url=https://packerswire.usatoday.com/2018/08/08/aaron-rodgers-sticks-up-for-player-protests-during-national-anthem//|publisher=''[[USAToday]]''|accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref> racism and injustice in the criminal system,<ref name="FoxNews">{{cite web|title=Hillary Clinton defends kneeling NFL players, says 'that's not against our anthem or flag'|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/10/16/hillary-clinton-defends-kneeling-nfl-players-says-thats-not-against-our-anthem-or-flag.html/|publisher=''[[Fox News]]''|accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref> oppression of people of color in the United States,<ref name="SBNation">{{cite web|title=Everything you need to know about NFL protests during the national anthem|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2017/9/29/16380080/donald-trump-nfl-colin-kaepernick-protests-national-anthem/|publisher=''[[SBNation]]''|accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref> and to not "show pride in a flag for a country that oppresses black people and people of color"<ref name="NFL">{{cite web|title=Colin Kaepernick explains why he sat during national anthem'|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000691077/article/colin-kaepernick-explains-protest-of-national-anthem/|publisher=''[[NFL.com]]''|accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> during the playing of the [[U.S. national anthem]].<ref name="insider.foxnews.com">{{cite news|title=Kevin Jackson: 'Kaepernick Effect' to Blame for NFL's Ratings Decline|date=September 23, 2017|website=FoxNews.com|url=http://insider.foxnews.com/2017/09/23/president-trump-slams-colin-kaepernick-nfl-national-anthem-protests-kevin-jackson-reacts|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170924064351/http://insider.foxnews.com/2017/09/23/president-trump-slams-colin-kaepernick-nfl-national-anthem-protests-kevin-jackson-reacts|archivedate=September 28, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Many players since 2017 have started to protest against the attacks of President [[Donald Trump]]<ref name="insider.foxnews.com"/> to those involved in the protest. The demonstrations have generated mixed reactions. Some have described them as politically urgent or patriotic, some other have criticized the fact their attention is attracted to such social problems during sports, while others have called the protests unpatriotic and disrespectful of the [[U.S. flag]], the national anthem, the [[Law enforcement in the United States|police]], and the [[United States Armed Forces|military]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Mindock|first=Clark|title=Taking a knee: Why are NFL players protesting and when did they start kneeling?|date=September 26, 2017|newspaper=The Independent|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/taking-a-knee-national-anthem-nfl-trump-why-meaning-origins-racism-us-colin-kaepernick-a7966961.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.independent.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fworld%2Famericas%2Fus-politics%2Ftaking-a-knee-national-anthem-nfl-trump-why-meaning-origins-racism-us-colin-kaepernick-a7966961.html&date=2017-09-27|archivedate=September 27, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Hafner|first=Josh|title=Anthem kneeling isn't aimed at veterans, and other NFL protest misconceptions|date=September 25, 2017|newspaper=USA Today|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/09/25/anthem-kneeling-isnt-aimed-veterans-and-other-nfl-protest-misconceptions/701409001/|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.usatoday.com%2Fstory%2Fnews%2Fnation-now%2F2017%2F09%2F25%2Fanthem-kneeling-isnt-aimed-veterans-and-other-nfl-protest-misconceptions%2F701409001%2F&date=2017-09-27|archivedate=September 27, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
The protests began in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) after [[San Francisco 49ers]] [[quarterback]] [[Colin Kaepernick]] sat and later [[knelt]] during the anthem, before his team's [[National Football League preseason|preseason]] games of [[2016 NFL season|2016]].<ref name="SB">{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2016/9/11/12869726/colin-kaepernick-national-anthem-protest-seahawks-brandon-marshall-nfl|title=A timeline of Colin Kaepernick's national anthem protest and the NFL players who joined him|last1=Sandritter|first1=Mark|publisher=SB Nation|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> Throughout the following seasons, members of various NFL and other sports teams have engaged in similar silent protests. On September 24, 2017, the NFL protests became more widespread when over 200 players sat or knelt in response to President [[Donald Trump]]'s calling for owners to "fire" the protesting players.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2017/09/24/donald-trump-nfl-player-protests-national-anthem-week-3-response/697609001/|title=NFL player protests sweep league after President Donald Trump's hostile remarks|work=USA Today|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref>
== Meaning behind protesting the U.S. national anthem and kneeling == {{further|U.S. national anthem protests}} It is a tradition in the United States to play "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]", the [[national anthem]], before sporting events.<ref name=":2" /> According to the [[United States Code]], those present should stand at attention with right hand over heart.<ref>{{usc|36|301}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Title 36 United States Code: § 301. National Anthem.|url= https://www.senate.gov/reference/resources/pdf/RL30243.pdf#page=11|publisher= [[United States Senate]]|date= October 31, 2016|accessdate= June 5, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-37208404|title= What must Americans do during the anthem?|date= September 25, 2017|work= BBC News|access-date= September 27, 2017|language= en-GB}}</ref> It's noteworthy, this tradition only acquired widespread practice after the year 2001, while [[National Football League]] (NFL) players were not mandated to be on the field for the playing of the national anthem until 2009.<ref name=":5">{{cite news|last= Willingham|first= AJ|title= The national anthem in sports (spoiler: it wasn't always this way)|url= http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/25/us/nfl-national-anthem-trump-kaepernick-history-trnd/index.html|publisher= [[Time Warner]]|website= CNN.com|date= September 25, 2017|accessdate= June 5, 2018}}</ref> In 2016 the NFL stated that "players are encouraged but not required to stand during the playing of the National Anthem"; its game operations manual reads that players "should stand" for the anthem.<ref>{{cite news|last= O'Malley|first= Nick|title= NFL rulebook does not require players to stand for national anthem; Game Operations manual does|date= September 26, 2017|work= MassLive.com|url= http://blog.masslive.com/patriots/2017/09/facebook_post_citing_nfl_playe.html|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20171010060237/http://blog.masslive.com/patriots/2017/09/facebook_post_citing_nfl_playe.html|archivedate= October 10, 2017|deadurl= no}}</ref>
The people of the United States is divided on the intended meaning of the anthem. Some believe it salutes military and police officers who have died on duty; for others, it honors the United States generally.<ref name=":2">{{cite news|last= Brady|first= Erik|title= How national anthem became essential part of sports|url= https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2017/09/26/how-national-anthem-become-essential-part-sports/706243001/|newspaper= USA Today|date= September 27, 2017|accessdate= June 5, 2018|language= en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1= Har|first1= Janie|last2= Contreras|first2= Russell|title= Diverse America divided on flag, anthem, other symbols|date= September 16, 2016|publisher= Associated Press|url= https://apnews.com/1959daeed38b466395f053f6f9b2dc52/diverse-america-divided-flag-anthem-other-symbols|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20171207181301/https://apnews.com/1959daeed38b466395f053f6f9b2dc52/diverse-america-divided-flag-anthem-other-symbols|archivedate= December 7, 2017|deadurl= no}}</ref> Between 2012 and 2015, the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] gave $6.8 million to teams across all major sports in exchange for holding various military and patriotic events at their games, including the performance of the national anthem.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite web|url= https://www.mccain.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/12de6dcb-d8d8-4a58-8795-562297f948c1/tackling-paid-patriotism-oversight-report.pdf|title= Tackling Paid Patriotism|last= McCain|first= John|last2= Flake|first2= Jeff|date= 2015|website= |archive-url= |archive-date= |dead-url= |access-date= }}</ref>
Kaepernick and his 49ers teammate [[Eric Reid (American football)|Eric Reid]] say they choose to kneel during the anthem to call attention to the issues of racial inequality and police brutality. "After hours of careful consideration, and even a visit from [[Nate Boyer]], a retired [[Special Forces (United States Army)|Green Beret]] and former NFL player, we came to the conclusion that we should kneel, rather than sit, ... during the anthem as a peaceful protest," said Reid. "We chose to kneel because it's a [[respect]]ful gesture. I remember thinking our posture was like a flag flown at half-mast to mark a tragedy."<ref>{{cite news|last= Reid|first= Eric|title= Opinion {{!}} Eric Reid: Why Colin Kaepernick and I Decided to Take a Knee|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/25/opinion/colin-kaepernick-football-protests.html|newspaper= [[The New York Times]]|date= September 25, 2017|access-date= September 27, 2017|language= en-US|issn= 0362-4331}}</ref> Some regard kneeling as disrespectful to those who have died or been wounded in service of the United States, such as police officers or military veterans.<ref>{{cite news|last= MacQuarrie|first= Brian|title= Military veterans divided over NFL protests|url= https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/09/25/military/MLjykBWSTbMlWqbaVUAGzI/story.html|newspaper= The Boston Globe|date= September 27, 2017|access-date= June 5, 2018}}</ref> Torrey Smith, a wide receiver for the Philadelphia Eagles, said in an interview: "I understand why people are offended by people protesting the National Anthem. My father served 25 years. When he dies, he's going to be wrapped in an American flag. But my dad is also out of the Army, and he drives trucks all over the country, and he's a black man everywhere he goes, and sometimes he has racial incidents still today. That doesn't protect him, just because he served our country. And I think that's important."<ref> {{Cite news|url= https://www.cnn.com/2017/09/27/us/nfl-anthem-protest-race-trump-trnd/index.html|title= The #TakeAKnee protests have always been about race. Period.|last= CNN|first= AJ Willingham,|work= CNN|access-date= 2018-06-18}} </ref>
== Reasons for the protest and related charity == [[Criminal justice reform in the United States|Criminal justice reform]] is one of the top issues that NFL players have been supporting in their protests.<ref>{{cite news|last=Reid|first=Jason|title=NFL owners, players are moving in the wrong direction|date=October 30, 2017|work=The Undefeated|url=https://theundefeated.com/features/nfl-owners-players-are-moving-in-the-wrong-direction/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171030163548/https://theundefeated.com/features/nfl-owners-players-are-moving-in-the-wrong-direction/|archivedate=October 30, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Kaepernick was initially moved to protest by the deaths of African Americans at the hands of police or while in police custody. These deaths gained prominence through the media and the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement in the years immediately preceding the protest.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2016/10/ruth_bader_ginsburg_s_kaepernick_comments_end_the_notorious_rbg_myth.html|title=Ruth Bader Ginsburg Was Never Really "Notorious RBG"|last=Stern|first=Mark Joseph|date=October 11, 2016|work=Slate|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.slate.com%2Farticles%2Fnews_and_politics%2Fjurisprudence%2F2016%2F10%2Fruth_bader_ginsburg_s_kaepernick_comments_end_the_notorious_rbg_myth.html&date=2017-09-27|archivedate=September 27, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> During a post-game interview on August 26, 2016, he stated, "I am not going to stand up to show pride in a flag for a country that oppresses black people and [[people of color]]. To me, this is bigger than football and it would be selfish on my part to look the other way. There are bodies in the street and people getting paid leave and getting away with murder", adding that he would continue to protest during the anthem until he feels like "[the United States flag] represents what it's supposed to represent."<ref name="wyche">{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000691077/article/colin-kaepernick-explains-protest-of-national-anthem|title=Colin Kaepernick explains why he sat during national anthem|last=Wyche|first=Steve|date=August 27, 2016|publisher=National Football League|accessdate=August 27, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/09/18/colin-kaepernick-nfl-black-lives-matter-protests-recall-rebellio/|title=Colin Kaepernick: NFL Black Lives Matter protests recall rebellious spirit of 1960s sporting greats|author=Nick Allen|date=September 18, 2016|website=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=November 8, 2016}}</ref>
After that interview, Kaepernick pledged to donate the first $1 million of his $11.9 million salary from the 2016–2017 season to different organizations that help communities in need.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/colin-kaepernick-says-hell-donate-1-million-to-charities-that-help-communities-in-need/|title=Colin Kaepernick to donate $1 million to charities that aid communities in need|last1=Wagner-McGough|first1=Sean|date=September 2, 2016|publisher=cbssports.com|accessdate=October 17, 2016}}</ref> He pledged to donate $100,000 per month for 10 months to various organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ninerswire.usatoday.com/2016/09/20/colin-kaepernick-to-donate-100k-a-month-for-10-months/|title=Colin Kaepernick to donate $100k a month for 10 months|last1=Biderman|first1=Chris|work=USA Today|format=September 20, 2016|accessdate=October 17, 2016}}</ref> Days later, the [[San Francisco 49ers]] matched Kaepernick by pledging $1 million to two organizations addressing racial and social inequality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/nfl/la-sp-colin-kaepernick-49ers-donation-20160908-snap-story.html|title=49ers to donate $1 million to charities that focus on racial issues cited by Colin Kaepernick|last1=Loumena|first1=Dan|date=September 9, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=October 17, 2016}}</ref> Kaepernick has been following through on his commitment and has donated $900,000 as of September 2017 to groups including [[Meals on Wheels]], United We Dream, Black Veterans for Social Justice and many others.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2017/08/colin-kaepernick-nfl-national-anthem-protest-one-million-dollar-pledge-donations-empower-communities|title=Colin Kaepernick has donated $800k to empower oppressed communities|date=August 23, 2017|work=For The Win|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/maurybrown/2017/09/15/dont-ignore-this-positive-pr-twist-to-colin-kaepernick/#77a7a1d35740|title=Don't Ignore This Positive PR Twist To Colin Kaepernick|last=Brown|first=Maury|work=Forbes|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en}}</ref> Kaepernick has also held "Know Your Rights" camps for young [[People of Color|people of color]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://knowyourrightscamp.com/about/|title=About Us – Know Your Rights Camp|website=knowyourrightscamp.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-01}}</ref> The camps include legal education from attorneys that give advice on how to interact with police when being detained and lectures from prominent academics on the history of the [[Civil Rights Movement]] in the United States.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/colin-kaepernicks-message-to-chicago-youth-know-your-rights/|title=Colin Kaepernick's Message to Chicago Youth: 'Know Your Rights'|last=Zirin|first=Dave|date=May 10, 2017|work=The Nation|access-date=September 27, 2017|issn=0027-8378}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2016/10/30/colin-kaepernick-holds-know-your-rights-camp-for-underprivileged-bay-area-kids/|title=Colin Kaepernick holds 'Know Your Rights' camp for underprivileged Bay Area kids|last=Bieler|first=Des|date=October 30, 2016|work=Washington Post|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> The [[National Football League Players Association]] (NFLPA) named Kaepernick the Week One MVP in September 2017 for his charity work related to the protest.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/09/15/nfl-players-union-names-colin-kaepernick-its-week-1-mvp-for-his-charity-work/|title=NFL players' union names Colin Kaepernick its Week 1 MVP for his charity work|last=Payne|first=Marissa|date=September 15, 2017|work=Washington Post|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
=== Trump calls for firing protesting players=== {{see also|Protests against Donald Trump}} [[File:Donald Trump with jersey, helmet and football of New England Patriots.jpg|thumb|President Trump meeting with the players and staff of [[New England Patriots]] at the [[White House]] on April 19, 2017 following their [[Super Bowl LI]] win over the [[Atlanta Falcons]].]] In September 2017, U.S. President [[Donald Trump]], speaking at a rally in Huntsville, Alabama, said NFL owners should fire players who kneel during the national anthem, and encouraged fans to walk out. Trump tried to use his position at the administration to advise NFL owners to say "Get that son of a bitch off the field right now, out, he's fired. He's fired!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/09/23/media/donald-trump-nfl-protest-backlash/index.html|title=With 'son of a bitch' comments, Trump tried to divide NFL and its players|last=Stelter|first=Brian}}</ref> Trump called the players' protest "a total disrespect of our heritage".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/22/trump-nfl-protests-football-243046|title=Trump sparks war with NFL – and LeBron|last=Griffiths|first=Brent D.|date=September 22, 2017|access-date=September 23, 2017|publisher=[[Politico]]|last2=Jackson|first2=Henry C.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-to-nfl-owners-fire-players-who-kneel-during-national-anthem/|title=Trump to NFL owners: Fire players who kneel during national anthem|date=September 23, 2017|publisher=CBS News}}</ref> He went on to say that new NFL safety rules meant to protect players from [[Concussions in American football|concussions]] are ruining the game for the public.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/09/26/congresswoman-trump-endangering-nfl-players-with-reckless-comments-about-safety/|title=Congresswoman: Trump endangering NFL players with 'reckless' comments about safety|last=Payne|first=Marissa|date=September 26, 2017|work=Washington Post|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> His statement came after new research indicates NFL players are at high risk for [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE) due to the likelihood of multiple head injuries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/07/25/539198429/study-cte-found-in-nearly-all-donated-nfl-player-brains|title=Study: CTE Found In Nearly All Donated NFL Player Brains|work=NPR.org|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
Trump denied his criticism of the protesters was related to race. "This has to do with respect for our country and respect for our flag," he said.<ref>{{cite news|first1=Bryan Armen|last1=Graham|first2=Martin|last2=Pengelly|title=NFL players kneel for anthem in unprecedented defiance of Trump|date=September 24, 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/sep/24/donald-trump-nfl-protests-kneel-anthem|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171026045803/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/sep/24/donald-trump-nfl-protests-kneel-anthem|archivedate=October 26, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> In the games immediately following Trump's statements, the protest gained broader participation when over 200 players sat or knelt during the anthem, others linked arms with their teammates or raised fists, and three teams chose to stay in the locker room for the anthem.<ref name=":3" /><ref name="SB" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/24/sports/nfl-trump-anthem-protests.html|title=After Trump Blasts N.F.L., Players Kneel and Lock Arms in Solidarity|last=Hoffman|first=Benjamin|date=September 24, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=September 27, 2017|last2=Mather|first2=Victor|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|last3=Fortin|first3=Jacey}}</ref> However, the response was more a reaction to Trump than Kaepernick's original protests of racial injustice.<ref name=":4"/><ref name="latimes.com">{{cite news|last1=Farmer|first1=Sam|last2=King|first2=Laura|title=As Trump continues his attacks, NFL players protest by kneeling or locking arms|date=September 24, 2017|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/nfl/la-sp-nfl-players-protest-trump-20170924-story.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.latimes.com%2Fsports%2Fnfl%2Fla-sp-nfl-players-protest-trump-20170924-story.html&date=2017-09-29|archivedate=September 29, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Jonathan|title=A Gesture of Support by NFL Owners Is Meaningless without Them Taking Real Action|date=September 26, 2017|website=SI.com|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/09/26/nfl-anthem-protests-team-owners-shad-khan-dan-snyder|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.si.com%2Fnfl%2F2017%2F09%2F26%2Fnfl-anthem-protests-team-owners-shad-khan-dan-snyder&date=2017-09-29|archivedate=September 29, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Reasons cited by players, owners, and coaches included supporting freedom of speech and opposing what they considered intimidation by Trump.<ref name=":4" /> Others said they took offense to Trump demeaning the integrity of their primarily African American colleagues, when a month earlier he had called the [[white nationalists]] who [[Unite the Right rally|protested in Charlottesville, Virginia]], "Very fine people".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2017/9/23/16354502/donald-trump-nfl-players-reactions-national-anthem-protests-twitter|title=NFL players respond with heat to Donald Trump's comments about protests|work=SBNation.com|access-date=September 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/nfl-eric-reid-donald-trump-race-row-neo-nazis-charlottesville-fine-people-president-us-latest-a7967811.html|title=NFL player who started anti-Trump movement: 'He refers to us with slurs but Charlottesville neo-Nazis as 'very fine people'|date=September 26, 2017|work=The Independent|access-date=September 27, 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref> The reaction to Trump's remarks overshadowed other ongoing issues his administration was facing, including failed [[American Health Care Act of 2017|attempts at healthcare reform]], the primary election loss of Trump-backed candidate [[Luther Strange]] for the [[United States Senate special election in Alabama, 2017|Alabama seat in the U.S. Senate]], recovery efforts for [[Hurricane Maria]] in Puerto Rico and [[Hurricane Harvey]] in [[Houston]], and [[North Korea–United States relations|relations with North Korea]] over their [[2017 North Korean nuclear test|nuclear]] and [[2017 North Korean missile tests|missile testing]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Donald Trump fuels NFL anthem row by tweeting year old video|date=October 1, 2017|newspaper=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/01/donald-trump-fuels-nfl-anthem-row-tweeting-year-old-video/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171001063651/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/01/donald-trump-fuels-nfl-anthem-row-tweeting-year-old-video/|archivedate=October 1, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Many players beyond the 2017 season have knelt or raised fists in protest against the policies of President [[Donald Trump]].<ref name=":4"/><ref name="latimes.com"/>
In May 2018 on an in interview President Donald Trump went as far to say "You have to stand proudly for the national anthem, or you shouldn’t be playing, you shouldn’t be there. Maybe you shouldn’t be in the country".<ref name="nbcnews.com">https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-says-nfl-players-who-kneel-during-national-anthem-maybe-n876996</ref> He went from his previous opinion that these NFL players should be fired to that they should "maybe" be deported. Trump applauded the new policy that NFL players must either stand for the anthem or stay back in the locker room, but felt that this policy was not strict enough. <ref name="nbcnews.com"/> Trump even wanted players to not be able to express political views even when off the field. <ref name="nbcnews.com"/>
==NFL protests==
===2016 preseason=== Kaepernick began sitting during the national anthem at the start of the 2016 NFL preseason. His actions went unnoticed for two weeks before he was questioned by the media.<ref>{{cite news|last=Levin|first=Josh|title=Colin Kaepernick's Protest Is Working|date=September 12, 2016|work=Slate|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/sports_nut/2016/09/colin_kaepernick_s_protest_is_working.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.slate.com%2Farticles%2Fsports%2Fsports_nut%2F2016%2F09%2Fcolin_kaepernick_s_protest_is_working.html&date=2017-09-27|archivedate=September 27, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> In the 49ers' final 2016 preseason game on September 1, 2016, after talking to Boyer, Kaepernick opted to kneel during the U.S. national anthem rather than sit as he did in their previous games. He explained his decision to switch was an attempt to show more respect to former and current U.S. military members while still protesting during the anthem. [[Eric Reid (American football)|Eric Reid]] joined Kaepernick in kneeling during the national anthem during the final preseason game.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/sep/01/colin-kaepernick-eric-reid-kneel-national-anthem-protest-san-francisco-49ers|title=Colin Kaepernick joined by Eric Reid in kneeling for national anthem protest|last=Press|first=Associated|date=September 1, 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|issn=0261-3077|access-date=September 7, 2016}}</ref> [[Seattle Seahawks]] player [[Jeremy Lane]] also did not stand for the anthem during his final preseason game the same day, stating, "It's something I plan to keep on doing until justice is being served."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/seahawks/2016/09/01/jeremy-lane-colin-kaepernick-national-anthem-protest/89752460/|title=Seahawks' Jeremy Lane joins Colin Kaepernick's protest, sits during national anthem|access-date=September 7, 2016}}</ref>
===2016 season=== In Week 1, eleven NFL players joined Kaepernick's protests.<ref name="breech">{{cite web|last1=Breech|first1=John|title=Here are the 11 players who joined Colin Kaepernick's protest in Week 1|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/here-are-the-11-players-who-joined-colin-kaepernicks-protest-in-week-1/|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> [[Denver Broncos]] player [[Brandon Marshall (linebacker)|Brandon Marshall]] knelt during the national anthem prior to the start of the [[National Football League Kickoff game|Kickoff game]], which was broadcast on [[NBC Sunday Night Football|NBC]].<ref name="money">{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=Nate|title=Broncos linebacker Brandon Marshall takes knee during national anthem|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2016/09/broncos-brandon-marshall-takes-knee-national-anthem-colin-kaepernick|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> The act of kneeling as protest has been referred to as "taking a knee".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/what-the-nfl-take-a-knee-protests-mean/2017/09/26/4915930e-a210-11e7-b573-8ec86cdfe1ed_story.html|title=Opinion {{!}} What the NFL take-a-knee protests mean|website=Washington Post|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/09/30/us/costas-nfl-cnntv/index.html|title=Bob Costas: Stand for anthem, then take a knee|last=CNN|first=Alexandra King,|work=CNN|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/taking-a-knee-national-anthem-nfl-trump-why-meaning-origins-racism-us-colin-kaepernick-a7966961.html|title=All you need to know about why NFL players are taking a knee and where it came from|date=2017-09-25|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-GB}}</ref> Kaepernick and Marshall were teammates at the [[University of Nevada]].<ref name="money"/> On September 11, [[Kansas City Chiefs]] player [[Marcus Peters]] [[raised fist|raised his fist]] while the rest of the team interlocked their arms showing solidarity.<ref name="time">{{cite news|last1=Gajanan|first1=Mahita|title=Kansas City Chiefs Cornerback Marcus Peters Raises Fist During National Anthem|url=http://time.com/4486853/kansas-city-chiefs-marcus-peters-national-anthem/|work=Time|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> Two members of the [[New England Patriots]], [[Devin McCourty]] and [[Martellus Bennett]], raised their fists on ''[[NBC Sunday Night Football|Sunday Night Football]]''. The entire Seattle Seahawks team stood and interlocked arms.<ref name="arnold">{{cite web|last1=Arnold|first1=Geoffrey|title=Seattle Seahawks lock arms during national anthem|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/nfl/index.ssf/2016/09/seattle_seahawks_lock_arms_dur.html|work=The Oregonian|accessdate=September 20, 2016}}</ref> [[Jelani Jenkins]], [[Arian Foster]], [[Kenny Stills]], and [[Michael Thomas (defensive back)|Michael Thomas]] of the [[Miami Dolphins]] all knelt during the National Anthem.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/sports/miami-dolphins-kneel-during-national-anthem/tVERFq0ty4uFmEqT2ULKCL/|title=4 Miami Dolphins kneel during national anthem|first=Hal|last=Habib|website=ajc}}</ref> At the same time, a group of [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] players, led by cornerback [[Prince Amukamara]], initially planned to join the protest but chose not to do so after photographs of Kaepernick wearing socks with a crude anti-police message during training camp were made public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/jacksonville-jaguars/post/_/id/19870/jaguars-players-considered-protest-but-pig-socks-derailed-plans|title=Jaguars players considered protest, but pig socks scuttled plans|accessdate=December 16, 2016}}</ref>
On November 13, 2016, 5 days after [[Donald Trump]] was [[United States presidential election, 2016|elected]] [[President of the United States|President]], [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] wide-receiver [[Mike Evans (wide receiver)|Mike Evans]] decided to sit during the national anthem. According to ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', Evans said, "If this happens, then America's not right right now. I said this a long time ago. When he ran, I thought it was a joke, and the joke continues. I'm not a political person that much, but I got common sense. And I know when something's not right."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/mike-evans-sat-during-anthem-to-protest-donald-trump-presidency/ |title=Mike Evans sat during anthem to protest Donald Trump presidency |publisher=CBSSports.com |access-date=November 27, 2016}}</ref> However, his protest began the day following [[Veterans Day]], so he received criticism. He quickly changed his method of protesting and joined his teammates during the following game against the Kansas City Chiefs. He apologized to veterans and other members of the military for his actions – citing that the timing of his protest was poor. "On the field, I'm going to continue to do what I do – play hard. I'm playing hard because I've got this right – freedom, because of the vets. I'm going to reach out to organizations, organizations that I feel are doing the best job to help the minority ... women, LGBT, African Americans, Latinos, people that are in fear of Donald Trump and his presidency."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.espn.com/blog/tampa-bay-buccaneers/post/_/id/15124/bucs-mike-evans-stands-for-national-anthem |title=Bucs' Mike Evans ends protest, stands for national anthem |publisher=ESPN |access-date=November 27, 2016}}</ref>
===2017 season=== [[File:Oakland Raiders National Anthem Kneeling (37444579735).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Oakland Raiders players [[kneeling]] in week{{nbsp}}3]] [[Cleveland Browns]] tight end [[Seth DeValve]] became the first white football player to kneel or sit during the anthem on the team's August 21, 2017 preseason game against the [[New York Giants]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadspin.com/seth-devalve-is-the-first-white-player-to-kneel-for-the-1798295618|title=Seth DeValve Is The First White Player To Kneel for the National Anthem|last=Baccellieri|first=Emma}}</ref> [[File:Washington Redskins National Anthem Kneeling (37301887651) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright=1.85|Washington Redskins players kneeling before the game with the Oakland Raiders]] [[File:San Francisco 49ers National Anthem Kneeling (37721041581).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Members of the San Francisco 49ers kneeling during the National Anthem before a game against the Washington Redskins in week 6]] <!-- See talk page for a discussion regarding this list. --> In Week 3 of the season the majority of games were played two days after Trump made his statements.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Graham|first1=Bryan|title=Donald Trump blasts NFL anthem protesters: 'Get that son of a bitch off the field'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/sep/22/donald-trump-nfl-national-anthem-protests|website=theguardian|publisher=Guardian News|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> The protest gained broader participation when over 200 players sat or knelt during the anthem.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="SB" /><ref name=":3">{{cite news|title=Cowboys are one of six NFL teams that haven't had a player kneel, sit or raise a fist during national anthem|date=September 25, 2017|newspaper=The Dallas Morning News|url=https://sportsday.dallasnews.com/dallas-cowboys/cowboys/2017/09/25/cowboys-one-six-nfl-teams-player-kneel-sit-national-anthem|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fsportsday.dallasnews.com%2Fdallas-cowboys%2Fcowboys%2F2017%2F09%2F25%2Fcowboys-one-six-nfl-teams-player-kneel-sit-national-anthem&date=2017-09-27|archivedate=September 27, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Many players, coaches and NFL teams protested and/or issued statements expressing dismay with Trump's comments:<ref name="ESPN.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/nflnation/post/_/id/249755/nfl-players-who-protested-during-the-national-anthem-in-week-3|title=NFL players who protested during the national anthem in Week 3|publisher=ESPN|access-date=September 24, 2017}}</ref> * Twenty-seven members of the [[Baltimore Ravens]] and [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] knelt during the American National Anthem at their game at [[Wembley Stadium]] in London.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/sep/24/donald-trump-defied-wembley-jaguars-ravens-nfl-kneel-anthem|title=Donald Trump defied at Wembley as Jaguars and Ravens kneel for anthem|last=Wembley|first=Sean Ingle at|date=September 24, 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=September 25, 2017|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Retired Ravens star and honorary Team Captain [[Ray Lewis]] knelt with members of his team.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/ravens/ravens-insider/bs-sp-ravens-anthem-protest-20170924-story.html|title=Some Ravens and Jaguars take knee during national anthem in wake of comments by President Trump|last=Zrebiec|first=Jeff|work=The Baltimore Sun|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> All of the players stood for the British national anthem "[[God Save the Queen]]" with many remaining in locked arms.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Sweeney|first=Don|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/article175130091.html|title=NFL players in London kneel for the US national anthem but stand for the British one|work=The Miami Herald|date=September 24, 2017|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> * Several members of the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] raised their fists during the anthem before their game against the [[New York Giants]]. Before the same game, various Giants players stood with arms locked while others knelt.<ref name="NYTimes">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/24/sports/nfl-trump-anthem-protests.html |title=Tom Brady Joins Anthem Demonstration as N.F.L. Protests Trump Comments |last=Belson |first=Ken |last2=Manchester |first2=Sam |date=September 24, 2017 |website=The New York Times |access-date=September 24, 2017 |last3=Mather |first3=Victor}}</ref> * The [[Seattle Seahawks]] and the [[Tennessee Titans]] did not take the field during the playing of the anthem, staying in their locker rooms until it concluded. The players of the Seahawks released a statement saying, "We will not stand for the injustice that has plagued people of color in this country. Out of love for our country and in honor of the sacrifices made on our behalf, we unite to oppose those that would deny our most basic freedoms."<ref name="ESPN.com"/> [[Meghan Linsey]], the Nashville singer who performed the anthem, knelt when she completed the song.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/sports/nfl/titans/2017/09/24/meghan-linsey-kneels-after-singing-national-anthem-titans-seahawks-game/698362001/|title=Meghan Linsey kneels after singing national anthem at Titans-Seahawks game|work=The Tennessean|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> * Before the opening of their game against the [[Houston Texans]], various [[New England Patriots]] players and staff also expressed their concerns, including quarterback [[Tom Brady]] locking arms with [[Phillip Dorsett]], and head coach [[Bill Belichick]] crossing his arms in front of him. Sixteen members of the Patriots knelt during the anthem.<ref name=":0" /> Patriots owner [[Robert Kraft]] said he was disappointed at the tone in which Trump's comments were made.<ref name="NYTimes"/> * Several members of the [[Miami Dolphins]] wore "#IMWITHKAP" T-shirts on the field during the pregame warmup, in support of Kaepernick's actions.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2017/09/24/donald-trump-nfl-player-protests-national-anthem-week-3-response/697609001/|title=NFL player protests sweep league after President Donald Trump's hostile remarks|work=USA Today|access-date=September 24, 2017}}</ref> The team locked arms during the anthem, with five members kneeling. The opposing team, the [[New York Jets]], also linked arms during the anthem.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/nfl/miami-dolphins/article175171896.html|title=Why did Stills kneel Sunday? Because he felt Trump tried to 'scare' or 'intimidate' him|work=The Miami Herald|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> * All [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] players except [[Alejandro Villanueva (American football)|Alejandro Villanueva]], who served as an [[United States Army Rangers|Army Ranger]], refused to leave the locker room during the anthem. On the sideline, the [[Chicago Bears]] players locked their arms while the anthem was performed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://wgntv.com/2017/09/24/nfl-sunday-kicks-off-amid-beef-between-players-trump/|title=From Chicago to London, NFL players react to Trump's protest critiques|date=September 24, 2017|publisher=WGN-TV|access-date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> Villanueva has since expressed regret for his actions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/nation_world/villanueva-on-anthem-flap-it-wasn-t-me-stepping-forward/article_62177918-7571-5d91-9bbf-f2337ea908ef.html|title=Villanueva on anthem flap: 'It wasn't me stepping forward'|last=Press|first=Associated|work=Winston-Salem Journal|access-date=2017-10-09|language=en}}</ref> * The majority of the [[Oakland Raiders]] either sat or knelt during the anthem, with several members of the opposing [[Washington Redskins]] either kneeling or joining arms as well.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/09/24/raiders-sit-during-national-anthem-they-couldnt-stay-locker-room|title=Most of the Raiders took a seat during national
